Hello...

It's Me...

JK. Welcome!

Let me first introduce myself. I am a senior double majoring in both Mathematics and Mathematical Economics from Pomona College. Though my second-home-of-a-dorm is in the Los Angeles, California area, my true home and feelings reside back in Austin, Texas, the city I grew up in, and the city I love.

With my time at Pomona College and as a Sagehen coming closer to an end, I am now happy to say that my new home, and thus my new adventure in life, will be in Washington, D.C. as I begin my economist career as a Research Assistant for the Federal Reserve Board come summer of 2017.

I have intentions of furthering my education past undergraduate studies eventually. Specifically, I will be working at the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System in Washington, D.C., come summer of 2017, as an Economics Research Assistant. Working at the Federal Reserve Board will expand and refine my knowledge in Applied and Theoretical Econometrics; Econometric Methodology; Macroeconomics; and Mathematical Economics. I also desire to pursue a career that utilises data analysis, visualisation, and manipulation. I am greatly interested in careers that not only utilise and analyse data, but also consult others with help from data.


Part

Economist

Mathematician

Why Economics?

Economics is not the study of money, and not about the exchange of money. Building upon that, economics is not analagous to finance. Instead, economics can be thought of as the study of choice. From what lunch you had to deciding what major you want to choose in college, economics is one of the unique fields of academia that can partially, if not fully, explain the effects of all the choices you have made. However, the main reason I was drawn to economics is because it fully utilises mathematics to build the fundamental theorems of economics. This unique combination of social sciences and mathematics is what makes economics so powerful, and so appealing.

Why Mathematics?

Everything can be thought of as a result of mathematics. From the computer you're using to the mechanics of your body that allow you to eat, most, if not all, of such objects and activities can be modelled mathematically. It is this definitive property that draws me to mathematically so profoundly. By realising this fact, and by studying mathematics not as a tool, but as a field, you're further realise that mathematics is not just an area of technicality; it is an art that can help you solve anything you desire.

... Here Is My Love To Do Research ...

SEP 2016 - PRESENT

MATHEMATICAL MODELLING OF TUBERCULOSIS (TB)

Mathematics Thesis

In Progress

Abstract Mathematical modelling techniques were utilised to model the spread of tuberculosis (TB) within a population. Techniques mainly revolved around the field of differential equations through application of conservation principles and analysis of equilibria. Specifically, differential equation was used through the study of the compartmental Susceptible-Infective-Recovery (SIR) model in order to have a basic understanding of how modelling of diseases within a population works. The SIR model was then changed to account for vaccinations and a latency period in order to align more closely to the actual workings of TB. The new model, called the Susceptible-Exposed/Latent-Infective-Recovery (SEIR/SLIR) model, is therefore derived and analysed to see what determines population equilibria in the presence of TB.

Available when complete
NOV 2016 - DEC 2016

TESTING THE CASH FLOW THEORY OF INVESTMENT

In Progress

  • Utilised Economic Census data, industry concentration levels can be obtained across NAICS codes, from 1997-2012, in 5 year increments
  • Utilised National Science Foundation data to obtain information on domestic R&D expenditure; domestic net sales; and number of employees within industries categorised by NAICS codes.
  • Discovered via regression models that the Cash Flow Theory of Investment holds for manufacturing industries, but is not strongly seen in non-manufacturing industries.
Full paper here
SEP 2016 - PRESENT

INVESTIGATING TRENDS BETWEEN ENTREPRENEURSHIP & FINANCING

In Progress

  • Investigating trends between entrepreneurship and financing
  • Collecting and cleaning data regarding to Initial Public Offerings (IPOs) and Mergers & Acquisitions (M&As) that have all occurred over the last 3 to 4 decades in the US economy
  • Analyse for trends between these IPOs and M&As from the newly created database
  • Summarise relevant literature about the desired research topic
  • Investigate potential determinants of a worker in the labour force swtiching into self-employment
  • Attempt to model these determinants and self-employment through probit/logit regression models
  • Merge common information between the Survey of Consumer Finances (SCF) and Current Population Survey (CPS) datasets
Available when complete
JAN 2016 - MAY 2016

USING STATISTICAL MULTI-LINEAR REGRESSION METHODS TO MODEL RELATIONSHIPS BETWEEN A DIAMOND'S PRICE & ITS CHARACTERISTICS

  • Coded in R & Stata
  • Utilised OLS, ridge, and LOESS regression; ANOVA; heteroscedasticity tests; hypothesis tests; confidence and prediction intervals; and variable selection to investigate the relationships between a diamond's sales price and its various characteristics
  • Dataset cleaned and used had over 53,000 data points with 10 variables
Full paper here
JAN 2016 - MAY 2016

USING ECONOMETRIC METHODOLOGY TO INVESTIGATE ECONOMIC GROWTH RATES & POWERLIFTING'S WILKS COEFFICIENT

  • Coded in R & Stata
  • Part III: Investigated whether the Wilks Coefficient is a measure of powerlifting performance that's unbiased with respect to weight, age, and sex
  • Used multi-linear regression methods to investigate the most influential factors towards the growth rate of countries from the 1960's to the 1990's
Full paper here
JAN 2015 - MAY 2015

AN ECONOMIC & STATISTICAL RESEARCH PERTAINING TO POSSIBLE ASSOCIATIONS BETWEEN RISK AVERSION AND SOCIO-ECONOMIC STATUS

  • Coded entirely in Stata and used multi-linear regression analysis
  • Found evidence for negative linear relationship between socio-economic status and absolute risk aversion
  • Dataset cleaned and used had over 500 data points
Full paper here
SEP 2015 - DEC 2015

A CORPORATE FINANCIAL REPORT ON THE SEMICONDUCTORS INDUSTRY

  • Investigated the financial performance of three core firms of the semiconductor industry (Intel, AMD, HP) using a variety of corporate financial metrics to speculate on the health of said industry
  • Calculated and analysed metrics such as betas of equity, the Sharpe ratio, the growth rates of each firm, both idiosyncratic and systematic risk, and more
Full paper here

Interactive Dashboard of the Winter Olympics Games

  • Dataset cleaned and used was over 82,000 points with 10 variables
  • Allows user input of country; region; sport; Olympic year; and medal count for isolated metrics

Interactive Dashboard of the Summer Olympics Games

  • Tableau dashboard that displays several metrics regarding to performance in the Summer and Winter Olympic Games
  • Dataset cleaned and used was over 82,000 points with 10 variables
  • Allows user input of country; region; sport; Olympic year; and medal count for isolated metrics

Abstract

Vacuum Thermal Evaporation (VTE) is a process that applies heat to solid material (e.g., metal) and allows this material to evaporate and deposite directly onto a substrate. These particles eventually condense and form a thin film of material which can be used in microfabrication. Our client, Professor Brian Bryce from the Engineering Department of Harvey Mudd College, created a high vacuum that implements this process and has tasked our team to create a shutter mechanism that can block metal deposition when closed and expose the inner area of the vacuum tube when opened. In this report, we detail the design process that resulted in our final prototype. Our proposed design is a 3D-printed model of a Slab Shutter that satisfies all our constraints and fulfills our objectives identified in this project. We also present recommendations to improve our current design for future iterations.

Objectives Pairwise Comparison Chart

Ranked design objectives in terms of client's personal preference and desires.

Best-of-Class Chart Metrics

The metrics and criteria of how we ranked our shutter design alternatives in the Best-of-Class chart. These metrics are either tested, calculated, or rationalised.

Ranked Morph Chart

Ranked the best means for each of the client's desired functions for the prototype. Best rank are means in the first row, and go down by decreasing ranking.

Design Alternative: Fan Shutter

This design would incorporate a gear system to move a series of overlapping steel blades from one end of the cylindrical opening to the other end. Each circular blade would be attached to the blade below and above it via a single locking joint, from which the blade would pivor anti-clockwise until concealing the cylindrical opening. The gearing system would be actuated by an external rod found currently on the outside of the vacuum, from which an individual would begin movement of the rod clockwise.

Design Alternative: Leaf Shutter

This design would incorporate a belt system to move a series of interlocking steel blades in a centripetal and centrifugal motion. Mounted to a housing periphery on the rim of the aperture, each blade would slide along a guiding trach via a small rod and take the shape of a circular sector. The belt system would be actuated by rotation of a rod found on the outside of the vacuum. This belt system would then translate kinetic rotational energy to centripetal and centrifugal motion by attaching to a rod located alongside the bottom of the leaf shutter, whih is attached to one of the guiding rods.

It should be noted that this design is from GrabCAD, and that we have no creator rights and ownership over this design whatsoever.

Design Alternative: Slab Shutter

This design is very closely aligned with viewport shutters sold commercially through venders like Kurt J. Lesker. The Slab Shutter features an arch-shaped flapper slab mounted on a tangential axis. This slab is rotated by a belt system, whereby the rotation of the slab in the Z-direciton is actuated by an external rod.

Design Alternative: Heart-Valve Shutter

This design was inspired by mechanical heart valves which are used for patients who have severe valvular disorder. The heart-valve shutter deisng features two semicircular steel slabs which pivot on two different rods. The rotary feed-through would initiate motion of the belt system, thereby opening closing the slabs. The slabs open ninety degrees so that when fully opened they run perpendicular to the periphery of the device.

Ranked Best-of-Class Chart

The metrics mentioned before were used to rank the performance of the four design alternatives.

We found the slab shutter performed the best in terms of the metrics for each objective.

Final Shutter Design

Final version of our chosen Slab Shutter design. The CAD file is a SolidWorks assembly file.

Components of the shutter include:

  • ISO 160 Flange
  • Slab
  • Plate
  • Cap
  • Attached Rod
  • Rotary Rod Extension
